div.p:
Here, stand behind this
bulk; straight will he come:

Wear thy good rapier bare,
and put it home:

Quick, quick; fear nothing;
I'll be at thy elbow:

It makes us, or it mars
us; think on that,

And fix most firm thy
resolution.

Be near at hand; I may
miscarry in't.

Here, at thy hand: be
bold, and take thy stand.

I have no great devotion
to the deed;

Yet he hath given me
satisfying reasons:

I have rubb'd this young
quat almost to the sense,

Or Cassio him, or each do
kill the other,

Every way makes my gain:
live Roderigo,

He calls me to a
restitution large

Of gold and jewels that I
bobb'd from him,

It must not be: if Cassio
do remain,

He has a daily beauty in
his life

That makes me ugly;
besides, the Moor

May unfold me to him; there
stand I in much peril:

Be it so: I hear him
coming.

Thrust had been mine enemy
indeed,

But that my coat is better
than thou know'st

I will make proof of
thine.

O brave Iago, honest and
just.

And my unblest fate hies:
strumpet, I come.

Thy bed, lust-stain'd,
shall with lust's blood be
spotted.

'Tis some mischance; which
is very direful.

Hark! two or three groan:
it is a heavy night:

These may be counterfeits:
let's think't unsafe

To come in to the cry
without more help.

Here's one comes in his
shirt, with weapons.

Whose noise is this that
cries on murder?
Did not you hear a cry?

This is Othello's ancient,
as I take it.

The same indeed; a very
valiant fellow.

What are you here that cry
so grievously?

O, I am spoil'd, undone by
villains!

I think that one of them
is hereabout,

Come in, and give some
help.

As you shall prove us,
praise us.

Light; I'll bind it with
my shirt.

Who they should be that
have thus have many led
you?

I am sorry to find you thus:
I have been to seek you.

Gentlemen all, I do
suspect this trash

To be a party in this
injury.
Know we this face or no?

Alas my friend, my dear
countryman Roderigo!

Even he, sir; did you know
him?

These bloody accidents
must excuse my manners,
I am glad to see you.

He that lies slain here,
Cassio,

Was my dear friend: what
malice was between you?

None in the world; nor do
I know the man.

O, bear him out o' the
air.

Do you perceive the
gastness of her eye?

Nay, if you shall stare,
we shall hear more anon.
I pray you, look at her:

Even though tongues were
out of use.

Cassio hath been here set
on in the dark

By Roderigo and others who
are scaped:

He's almost slain, and
Roderigo quite dead.

This is the fruit of
whoring.

Go know of Cassio where he
supp'd to-night.

What, do you shake at
that?

He supp'd at my house; but
I therefore shake not.
I charge you, go with me.

I am no strumpet; but of
life as honest
As you that thus abuse me.

Kind gentlemen, let's go
see poor Cassio dress'd.

Come, mistress, you must
tell's another tale.

Emilia run you to the
citadel,

And tell my lord and lady
what hath happ'd.

That either makes me or
fordoes me quite.

It is the cause, it is the
cause, my soul--

Let me not name it to you,
you chaste stars!

Yet I'll not shed her
blood;

Nor scar that whiter skin
of hers than snow,

Yet she must die, else
she'll betray more men.

Put out the light, and
then put out the light:

If I quench thee, thou
flaming minister,

I can again thy former
light restore,

Should I repent me: but
once put out thy light,

Thou cunning'st pattern of
excelling nature,

I know not where is that
Promethean heat

When I have pluck'd thy
rose,

I cannot give it vital
growth again.
I'll smell it on the tree.

Ah balmy breath, that dost
almost persuade

Be thus when thou art dead,
and I will kill thee,

One more, and this the
last:

So sweet was ne'er so
fatal.

I must weep, But they are
cruel tears:

It strikes where it doth
love.

Will you come to bed, my
lord?

If you bethink yourself of
any crime

Unreconciled as yet to
heaven and grace,

Alack, what may you mean
by that?

Well, do it, and be brief;
I will walk by:

I would not kill thy
unprepared spirit;
I would not kill thy soul.

Then heaven have mercy on
me!

I hope you will not kill
me.

And yet I fear you; for
you are fearful then
I know not why I fear,

Since guiltiness I know
not; and yet I feel I fear.

They are loves I bear to
thee.

Ay, and for that thou
diest.

That death's unnatural
that kills for loving.

Why gnaw you so your
nether lip?

The bloody passion shakes
your very frame:

These are portents; and
yet I hope, I hope,
They do not point at me.

That handkerchief which I
so loved and gave thee
No, by my life and soul!

Send for the man, and ask
him.

Take heed of perjury; thou
art on thy deathbed.
Ay, but not yet to die.

Therefore confess thee
freely of thy sin;

For to deny each article
with oath

Cannot remove nor choke
the strong conception

Then Lord have mercy on
me!

Offend you in my life;
never loved Cassio

But by such general
warranty of heaven

As I might love: I never
gave him token.

By heaven, I saw my
handkerchief in's hand.

And makest me call what I
intend to do

A murder, which I thought
a sacrifice:

I never gave it him: send
for him hither;

Honest Iago hath ta'en
order for't.

My fear interprets: what,
is he dead?

Had all his hairs been
lives, my great revenge

He is betray'd and I
undone.

Weep'st thou for him to my
face?

O, banish me, my lord, but
kill me not!

Kill me to-morrow: let me
live to-night!

I that am cruel am yet
merciful;

I would not have thee
linger in thy pain:

'Tis like she comes to
speak of Cassio's death.

I think she stirs again:
no.

If she come in, she'll
sure speak to my wife:

Methinks it should be now
a huge eclipse

Of sun and moon, and that
the affrighted globe

I had forgot thee: O, come
in, Emilia;

What's the matter with
thee now?

O, my good lord, yonder's
foul murders done!

It is the very error of
the moon;

She comes more nearer
earth than she was wont,

Cassio, my lord, hath
kill'd a young Venetian
call'd Roderigo.

O, who hath done this
deed?

Commend me to my kind
lord:

Why, how should she be
murder'd?

You heard her say herself,
it was not I.

She said so: I must needs
report the truth.

She's, like a liar, gone
to burning hell:

She turn'd to folly, and
she was a whore.

Thou dost belie her, and
thou art a devil.

Thou art rash as fire, to
say

That she was false: O, she
was heavenly true!

Cassio did top her; ask
thy husband else.

O, I were damn'd beneath
all depth in hell,

But that I did proceed
upon just grounds

That she was false to
wedlock?

If heaven would make me
such another world

Of one entire and perfect
chrysolite, I'd not have
sold her for it.

Thy husband, ay, 'twas he
that told me first:

An honest man he is, and
hates the slime

O mistress, villany hath
made mocks with love,

My husband say that she
was false!

He, woman; I say thy
husband: dost understand
the word?

My friend, thy husband,
honest, honest Iago.

If he say so, may his
pernicious soul
Rot half a grain a day!

She was too fond of her
most filthy bargain.

This deed of thine is no
more worthy heaven

Thou hast not half that
power to do me harm
As I have to be hurt.

Thou hast done a deed-- I
care not for thy sword;

The Moor hath kill'd my
mistress!

That men must lay their
murders on your neck.

Disprove this villain, if
thou be'st a man:

He says thou told'st him
that his wife was false:

I know thou didst not,
thou'rt not such a villain:

Do speak, for my heart is
full.

I told him what I thought,
and told no more

Than what he found himself
was apt and true.

But did you ever tell him
she was false?

You told a lie, an odious,
damned lie;

Upon my soul, a wicked
lie.

She false with Cassio did
you say with Cassio?

I will not charm my
tongue;

My mistress here lies
murder'd in her bed--

And your reports have set
the murder on.

I thought so then-- O, I'll
kill myself for grief--

I charge you, get you
home.

I pray you, give me leave
to speak:

'Tis proper I obey him,
but not now.

Perchance, Iago, I will
ne'er go home.

Nay, lay thee down and
roar;

For thou hast kill'd the
sweetest innocent
That e'er did lift up eye.

I scarce did know you, uncle:
there lies your niece,

Whose breath, indeed, these
hands have newly stopp'd:

I know this act shows
horrible and grim.

I am glad thy father's
dead:

Thy match was mortal to
him, and pure grief

Shore his old thread in
twain: did he live now,

This sight would make him
do a desperate turn,

Yea, curse his better
angel from his side,

That she with Cassio hath
the act of shame

A thousand times committed;
Cassio confess'd it:

And she did gratify his
amorous works

With that recognizance and
pledge of love

Which I first gave her; I
saw it in his hand:

It was a handkerchief, an
antique token

No, I will speak as
liberal as the north:

Let heaven and men and
devils, let them all,

All, all, cry shame against
me, yet I'll speak.
Be wise, and get you home.

I found by fortune and did
give my husband;

For often, with a solemn
earnestness,

More than indeed belong'd
to such a trifle,

He begg'd of me to steal
it.

And I did give't my
husband.

By heaven, I do not, I do
not, gentlemen.

What would such a fool do
with so good a wife?

Are there no stones in
heaven

But what serve as for the
thunder?

The woman falls; sure, he
hath kill'd his wife.

Ay: O, O lay me by my
mistress' side.

He's gone, but his wife's
kill'd.

Which I have here
recover'd from the Moor:

Guard the door without;
let him not pass,

I'll after that same villain,
for 'tis a damned slave.

But every puny whipster
gets my sword:

But why should honour
outlive honesty?

What did thy song bode,
lady?

O Moor, she was chaste; she
loved thee, cruel Moor;

So come my soul to bliss,
as I speak true;

And speaking as I think,
alas, I die.

I have another weapon in
this chamber;

It was a sword of Spain,
the ice-brook's temper--

If thou attempt it, it
will cost thee dear:

Thou hast no weapon, and
perforce must suffer.

Look in upon me then and
speak with me,

Or, naked as I am, I will
assault thee.

A better never did sustain
itself

Upon a soldier's thigh: I
have seen the day,

That, with this little arm
and this good sword,

I have made my way through
more impediments

Than twenty times your
stop: but, O vain boast!

Be not afraid, though you
do see me weapon'd;

Here is my journey's end,
here is my butt,

And very sea-mark of my
utmost sail.

Man but a rush against
Othello's breast,

Now, how dost thou look
now?

When we shall meet at
compt,

This look of thine will
hurl my soul from heaven,

And fiends will snatch at
it.

From the possession of
this heavenly sight!

Wash me in steep-down
gulfs of liquid fire!

Where is this rash and
most unfortunate man?

That's he that was
Othello: here I am.

I look down towards his
feet; but that's a fable.

If that thou best a devil,
I cannot kill thee.

I bleed, sir; but not
kill'd.

I am not sorry neither:
I'ld have thee live;

For, in my sense, 'tis
happiness to die.

O thou Othello, that wert
once so good,

Fall'n in the practise of
a damned slave,

What shall be said to
thee?

An honourable murderer, if
you will;

For nought I did in hate,
but all in honour.

This wretch hath part
confess'd his villany:

Did you and he consent in
Cassio's death?

Dear general, I never gave
you cause.

I do believe it, and I ask
your pardon.

Will you, I pray, demand
that demi-devil

Why he hath thus ensnared
my soul and body?

Demand me nothing: what
you know, you know:

From this time forth I
never will speak word.

Sir, you shall understand
what hath befall'n,

Which, as I think, you
know not.

Found in the pocket of the
slain Roderigo;

And here another: the one
of them imports

The death of Cassio to be
undertook by Roderigo.

Found in his pocket too;
and this, it seems,

Roderigo meant to have
sent this damned villain;

But that belike Iago in
the nick

How came you, Cassio, by
that handkerchief
I found it in my chamber:

And he himself confess'd
it even now

That there he dropp'd it
for a special purpose

There is besides in
Roderigo's letter,

How he upbraids Iago, that
he made him

Brave me upon the watch;
whereon it came

I was cast: and even but
now he spake,

After long seeming dead,
Iago hurt him,

You must forsake this
room, and go with us:

Your power and your
command is taken off,

If there be any cunning
cruelty

That can torment him much
and hold him long,

Till that the nature of
your fault be known

Soft you; a word or two
before you go.

I have done the state some
service, and they know't.

I pray you, in your
letters,

When you shall these
unlucky deeds relate,

Speak of me as I am;
nothing extenuate,

Nor set down aught in
malice: then must you
speak

Of one that loved not
wisely but too well;

Of one not easily jealous,
but being wrought

Like the base Indian,
threw a pearl away

Richer than all his tribe;
of one whose subdued eyes,

Albeit unused to the
melting mood,

Drop tears as fast as the
Arabian trees

And say besides, that in
Aleppo once,

Where a malignant and a
turban'd Turk

Beat a Venetian and
traduced the state,

I took by the throat the
circumcised dog,

I kiss'd thee ere I kill'd
thee: no way but this;

Killing myself, to die
upon a kiss.

This did I fear, but
thought he had no weapon;
For he was great of heart.

More fell than anguish,
hunger, or the sea!

Look on the tragic loading
of this bed;

This is thy work: the
object poisons sight;

And seize upon the
fortunes of the Moor,

Remains the censure of
this hellish villain;

The time, the place, the
torture:

Myself will straight
aboard: and to the state

This heavy act with heavy
heart relate.
